title: Cusworth Hall Park Walking Route

images.title: Richard Croft / Cusworth Hall
images.caption: Cusworth Hall. Built for William Wrightson by George Platt in 1740 and altered by James Paine shortly afterwards, now the Museum of South Yorkshire Life.

images.title: Richard Croft / Cusworth Park
images.caption: View to Doncaster across the parkland at Cusworth Hall

images.title: Richard Croft / Cusworth Country Park
images.caption: View across the lawns to the lake.

images.title: Steve F, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lakes view.

images.title: Richard Croft / Lady Isabella's Garden
images.caption: Lady Isabella's Garden. Formal garden at the hall, named after Lady Isabella Battie-Wrightson

images.title: Steve F, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View over Doncaster from the park.

description: Explore acres of historic parkland in this country park in Doncaster. The estate surrounds the Grade I listed Cusworth Hall and includes lakes, plantations and pleasure ground with dramatic views across the town. In the park there is an Italianate Chapel with beautiful ceiling paintings and an excellent museum with a collection of 36000 objects including accessories, toys and games and kitchen equipment. Look out for watervoles, kingfishers and green flowered heleborine orchids at the delightful lake. The Trans Pennine Trail runs just past the park so there is scope for continuing your walk along the River Don to Conisbrough.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Doncaster River Walk visits two of the highlights of the area at Sprotbrough Falls and the impressive Conisbrough Viaduct where you enjoy fine views from the top of structure.

display_address: Back Lane, Cusworth Village, Sprotbrough and Cusworth, Cusworth, Doncaster, South Yorkshire, England, DN5 7TU, United Kingdom
